{{More citations needed|date=December 2009}} The '''2010 Arctic Winter Games''' were held in [[Grande Prairie]], [[Alberta]], Canada from March 6 to 13th.<ref>[http://www.awg2010.org/ Arctic Winter Games 2010]</ref>
The [[Arctic Winter Games]] is an international biannual celebration of circumpolar sports and culture, held in [[Canada]] or [[Alaska]].
Over 2,000 athletes from nine teams ([[Alaska]], [[Northern Alberta|Alberta North]], [[Yukon]], [[Yamalo-Nenets Autonomous Okrug|Yamal-Nenets]], [[Northwest Territories]], [[Greenland]], [[Nunavik|Nunavik Québec]], [[Nunavut]] and [[Sami people|Saami]]) participated in the games.<ref name="CBC.ca">{{cite news| url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/north/story/2010/03/15/arctic-winter-games-closing-ceremony.html | work=CBC.ca | title=Arctic Winter Games wrap up | date=2010-03-16 | accessdate=2010-12-27}}</ref>
Sports included [[alpine skiing]], arctic sports, [[badminton]], [[basketball]], [[biathlon]], [[curling]], dene games, dog mushing, [[figure skating]], [[freestyle skiing]], [[gymnastics]], [[hockey]], [[indoor soccer]], [[snowboarding]], [[snowshoeing]], [[speed skating]], [[table tennis]], [[volleyball]] and [[wrestling]].<ref>[http://www.awg2010.org/sports_info.aspx Arctic Winter Games 2010: Sports]</ref>
The next Arctic Winter Games were held in 2012 in [[Whitehorse, Yukon]].<ref name="CBC.ca" />
==Medal tally== (Listed by number of medals achieved overall.)<ref>[http://awg2010.gems.pro/Result/MedalList.aspx?SiteMapTreeExpanded=91aa1f2f-4728-413a-b56c-bd44b20458a9&SetLanguage=en-GB Arctic Winter Games 2010: Medal standing]</ref> {| class="wikitable" |- ! Team ! Gold ! Silver ! Bronze ! Overall |- | {{flag|Alaska}} | 87 | 85 | 79 | 251 |- | {{flagicon|Alberta}} [[Northern Alberta|Alberta North]] | 43 | 56 | 46 | 145 |- | {{flag|Yukon}} | 37 | 37 | 27 | 101 |- | {{flag|Yamalo-Nenets Autonomous Okrug|name=Yamal-Nenets}} | 35 | 21 | 8 | 64 |- | {{flag|Northwest Territories}} | 31 | 28 | 48 | 107 |- | {{flag|Greenland}} | 18 | 16 | 15 | 49 |- | {{flag|Nunavut}} | 9 | 16 | 24 | 49 |- | {{flagicon|Quebec}} [[Nunavik|Nunavik Québec]] | 12 | 10 | 13 | 35 |- | {{flagicon|Sápmi}} [[Sami people|Saami]] | 3 | 5 | 2 | 10 |}
==See also== *[[2006 Arctic Winter Games]] *[[2008 Arctic Winter Games]]

revision.text:
[[File:Three point shoot.JPG|thumb|Basketball players in uniform during the [[FIBA]] Europe Cup Women Finals 2005]] A '''basketball uniform''' is a type of [[uniform]] worn by [[basketball]] players. Basketball uniforms consist of a [[Jersey (clothing)|jersey]] that features the number and last name of the player on the back, as well as [[shorts]] and [[athletic shoes]]. Within teams, players wear uniforms representing the team colors; the home team typically wears a lighter-colored uniform, while the visiting team wears a darker-colored uniform.
Different basketball leagues have different specifications for the type of uniform that is allowed on the court. Early in the history of the sport, basketball was played in any type of athletic attire, but by the 1900s, special uniforms were developed and marketed to basketball players. The style, cut, and fit of basketball uniforms evolved throughout subsequent decades, often modeled after the general fashion trends of the day.
==History== ===Jerseys and shorts=== [[File:Kansas U team 1899.jpg|thumb|The 1899 University of Kansas basketball team, demonstrating uniforms of sleeveless jerseys and long pants]] <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Munich 1972.jpg|thumb|Yugoslavia playing Czechoslovakia in the [[1972 Summer Olympics]]; the players wear short, tight-fitting uniforms typical of the 1970s]] --> [[File:Carmelo Anthony Nuggets.jpg|thumb|[[Carmelo Anthony]] wearing a modern-day NBA uniform, headband and arm bands as accessories]] Originally, basketball was played in any type of athletic attire, ranging from [[track suit]]s to [[American football|football]] uniforms. The first official basketball uniforms, as displayed in the [[Spalding (sports equipment)|Spalding]] catalog of 1901, featured three types of pants: knee-length padded pants, similar to those worn for playing football, as well as shorter pants and knee-length tights. There were two types of suggested jersey, a quarter-length sleeve and a sleeveless version.<ref name="Naismith1941">{{cite book|author=James Naismith|title=Basketball: Its Origin and Development|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yDKtaGdhZncC&pg=PA89|year=1941|publisher=U of Nebraska Press|isbn=0-8032-8370-9|pages=89-90}}</ref>
The long pants later evolved into medium-length shorts in the 1920s, and by the 1930s, the material used for jerseys changed from heavy [[wool]] to the lighter [[polyester]] and [[nylon]]. In the 1970s and 80s, uniforms became tighter-fitting and shorts were shorter, consistent with the overall fashion trends of these two decades.<ref name="Raatma2012">{{cite book|author=Lucia Raatma|title=The Curious, Captivating, Unusual History of Sports|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=k6om9avhJfoC&pg=PA13|date=1 January 2012|publisher=Capstone Press|isbn=978-1-4296-7537-6|page=13}}</ref> At this time, women's basketball uniforms transitioned from longer-sleeved uniforms to [[Sleeveless shirt|tank-top]] style jerseys similar to men's basketball uniforms, which more explicitly showed off players' muscle tone.<ref name="McCullough2007">{{cite book|author=Sarah McCullough|title=Construction of the Female Athletic Body: A Study of Women's Sport Uniforms|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ojp42Q-ihI4C&pg=PA76|year=2007|publisher=ProQuest|isbn=978-0-549-26375-3|pages=76–78}}</ref>
In 1984, [[Michael Jordan]] asked for longer shorts and helped popularize the move away from tight, short shorts toward the longer, baggier shorts worn by basketball players today.<ref name="LeBoutillier2011">{{cite book|author=Nate LeBoutillier|title=The Best of Everything Basketball Book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R9mlMwWQqJgC&pg=PA59|date=1 January 2011|publisher=Capstone|isbn=978-1-4296-5468-5|pages=58-59}}</ref><ref name="Slade2013">{{cite book|author=Suzanne Slade|title=The Technology of Basketball|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=otgFCniq8tsC&pg=PA20|date=1 January 2013|publisher=Capstone|isbn=978-1-4296-9956-3|pages=20–21}}</ref> Throughout the 1990s, basketball uniforms fell under the influence of [[hip hop]] culture, with shorts becoming longer and looser-fitting, team colors brighter, and designs more flashy and suggestive of rappers' [[bling]].<ref name="Lane2007">{{cite book|author=Jeffrey Lane|title=Under the Boards: The Cultural Revolution in Basketball|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nqEfWSh17IwC&pg=PA74|date=1 December 2007|publisher=U of Nebraska Press|isbn=0-8032-0755-7|page=41}}</ref> At the turn of the 21st century, basketball uniforms became even more oversized and loose-fitting; the arm holes in women's basketball jerseys remained smaller than men's, but were wide enough to reveal the players' [[sports bra]]s.<ref name="McCullough2007">{{cite book|author=Sarah McCullough|title=Construction of the Female Athletic Body: A Study of Women's Sport Uniforms|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ojp42Q-ihI4C&pg=PA76|year=2007|publisher=ProQuest|isbn=978-0-549-26375-3|pages=76–78}}</ref> [[File:John Wall (Celtics at Wizards 1-24-17).jpg|thumb|right|[[Jae Crowder]] and [[John Wall (basketball)|John Wall]] wearing the newly introduced sleeved basketball jerseys]]
====Sleeved jersey==== For the Christmas Day games of 2013, the NBA and its apparel partner [[Adidas]] introduced a newly designed sleeved jersey with large team and NBA logos on the front.<ref>{{cite web|last=Patt|first=Jason|title=NBA Christmas Day uniforms 2013: Teams to wear new sleeved jerseys|url=https://www.sbnation.com/nba/2013/12/25/5243450/2013-nba-christmas-jerseys|work=SBNation|accessdate=25 December 2013}}</ref> Marketers for the new uniforms realized that fans were unwilling to wear sleeveless jerseys in their day-to-day life and hoped the new sleeved jerseys would be more popular for everyday wear.<ref name=wsj>{{cite web|last=Holmes|first=Elizabeth|title=NBA Christmas Jerseys—Now With Sleeves|url=https://www.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304243904579195860755097586|work=WSJ Online|accessdate=25 December 2013}}</ref> However, it was also a "not-so-well-kept secret that the NBA wanted to implement jersey ads in the years following the introduction of sleeved jerseys" as the "sleeves allow more space for potential partners to add their corporate logos to jerseys" like association football (soccer). After the league deal with Adidas expired and [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] signed on as the new apparel partner, the sleeved jersey did not continue.<ref>[https://www.sbnation.com/nba/2017/10/6/16203076/nba-sleeved-jerseys-nike-lebron-james]</ref>
The sleeved jersey was controversial among players. LeBron James famously ripped the sleeves off during a prime time game against the [[New York Knicks]] in 2015, but in the [[2016 NBA Finals]] James convinced his teammates to wear the sleeved jerseys in Game 5 and again in the title-clinching Game 7.<ref>[https://www.sbnation.com/nba/2017/10/6/16203076/nba-sleeved-jerseys-nike-lebron-james]</ref><ref name="CavsAltUnis2015">{{cite news|title=Cavs Unveil Three New Alternate Uniforms for 2015-16 Season|url=http://www.nba.com/cavaliers/news/releases/jersey-announcement-151021|publisher=NBA Media Ventures, LLC|website=NBA.com/Cavaliers|date=October 21, 2015|accessdate=October 22, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.si.com/nba/2016/06/19/nba-finals-game-7-cavs-black-sleeved-jerseys-warriors|title=Cavs wearing sleeved jerseys in Game 7|last=|first=|date=19 June 2016|work=SI.com|access-date=2017-06-17|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cleveland.com/cavs/index.ssf/2017/06/cavaliers_wearing_black_jersey.html|title=Cavaliers wearing black jerseys for Game 2: 2017 NBA Finals|last=Vardon|first=Joe|date=4 June 2017|work=cleveland.com|access-date=2017-06-17|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name="CavaliersLogoSuite">{{cite news|title=Cavaliers Logo Suite Evolves to Modernize Look|url=http://www.nba.com/cavaliers/releases/updated-logo-170531|publisher=NBA Media Ventures, LLC|website=NBA.com/Cavaliers|date=May 31, 2017|accessdate=June 13, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nba/news/look-cavs-unveil-new-logos-add-black-to-color-scheme-before-start-of-nba-finals/|title=LOOK: Cavs unveil new logos, add black to color scheme before start of NBA Finals|last=Boone|first=Kyle|date=1 June 2017|work=CBSSports.com|access-date=2017-06-17|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}}</ref>
===Shoes=== In 1903, a special basketball shoe with suction cups to prevent slippage was added to the official basketball uniform demonstrated in the Spalding catalog.<ref name="Naismith1941">{{cite book|author=James Naismith|title=Basketball: Its Origin and Development|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yDKtaGdhZncC&pg=PA89|year=1941|publisher=U of Nebraska Press|isbn=0-8032-8370-9|pages=89-90}}</ref> Over the decades, different shoe brands and styles were popular as basketball shoes: [[Chuck Taylor All-Stars]] and [[Keds]] in the 1960s and 70s; [[Adidas]] and [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] leather [[high-tops]] in the late 1970s and 80s; and [[Air Jordans]] in the 1990s.<ref name="LeBoutillier2011">{{cite book|author=Nate LeBoutillier|title=The Best of Everything Basketball Book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R9mlMwWQqJgC&pg=PA59|date=1 January 2011|publisher=Capstone|isbn=978-1-4296-5468-5|pages=58-59}}</ref>
===Accessories=== In the 1970s, [[Slick Watts]] and [[Bill Walton]] began to wear headbands, which soon became popular with other players. [[Rick Barry]] popularized wrist-bands, and other players soon created variations, such as bands that covered their forearms or biceps. These were used to wipe off sweat, or simply worn as fashion statements.<ref name="LeBoutillier2011">{{cite book|author=Nate LeBoutillier|title=The Best of Everything Basketball Book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R9mlMwWQqJgC&pg=PA59|date=1 January 2011|publisher=Capstone|isbn=978-1-4296-5468-5|pages=58-59}}</ref>
==Modern day== ===United States basketball=== ====Rules and regulations==== In professional basketball leagues today, teams playing at home typically wear lighter-colored uniforms than the visiting team.<ref name="HarariOminsky2002">{{cite book|author1=P. J. Harari|author2=Dave Ominsky|title=Basketball Made Simple: A Spectator's Guide|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gtNDH_pR990C&pg=PA10|date=1 October 2002|publisher=First Base Sports, Inc.|isbn=978-1-884309-13-7|page=10}}</ref> As of the {{nbay|2017|app=season}}, the NBA has eliminated the distinction between designated "home" and "away" uniforms. The home team is now allowed to wear any uniform color it chooses, while its opponent may wear any color that sufficiently contrasts with the home team's choice.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Whitaker |first1=Lang |title=NBA, Nike unveil new uniforms for 2017-18 season |url=http://www.nba.com/article/2017/07/18/nba-nike-new-uniforms |website=NBA.com |accessdate=October 15, 2018 |date=July 18, 2017}}</ref>
In the [[NBA]], basketball shorts must fall at least 1 inch above the knee, and [[T-shirts]] cannot be worn under the jersey – however, they are permitted in American [[college basketball]]. Some NBA and [[WNBA]] teams have allowed sponsors' logos to appear on their uniforms.<ref name=nytWNBA>{{cite news|last=Sandomir|first=Richard|title=In W.N.B.A., Jersey Sponsorship Could Set New Standard|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/06/01/sports/basketball/01wnba.html?_r=0|accessdate=25 December 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=31 May 2009}}</ref>
====Material==== Uniforms are made of [[wicking]] material designed to absorb sweat and ensure that it evaporates faster.<ref name="Raatma2012">{{cite book|author=Lucia Raatma|title=The Curious, Captivating, Unusual History of Sports|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=k6om9avhJfoC&pg=PA13|date=1 January 2012|publisher=Capstone Press|isbn=978-1-4296-7537-6|page=13}}</ref> They are the product of a four-year study researching professional basketball players, who identified the need for fewer seams, lighter weight, and faster drying and cooling in their jerseys.<ref name="Slade2013">{{cite book|author=Suzanne Slade|title=The Technology of Basketball|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=otgFCniq8tsC&pg=PA20|date=1 January 2013|publisher=Capstone|isbn=978-1-4296-9956-3|pages=20–21}}</ref>
===International basketball leagues=== The main difference between U.S. basketball uniforms and those of other countries is the appearance of sponsorship iconography; European basketball uniforms are often covered in the logos of their sponsors (similar to association football), while the U.S. uniforms (like other major pro sports) feature the team wordmark/logo front and center.<ref name=bleacherreport>{{cite web|last=O'Brien|first=Dan|title=NBA Debate: Should the NBA Put Advertisements on Jerseys?|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/1124800-nba-debate-should-the-nba-put-advertisements-on-jerseys|work=The Bleacher Report|accessdate=25 December 2013}}</ref>
For the 2017-18 season, some U.S. teams have started putting sponsorship logos on their jerseys on the upper left of the jersey which is a maximum of 2.5 inches by 2.5 inches.<ref>[https://www.sbnation.com/2017/7/26/16036162/nba-jersey-patch-sponsor-tracker-2017-season]</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Sports|Fashion}} *[[Sportswear (activewear)]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links==
