{{Infobox stadium | name = Stade Félix Houphouët-Boigny | nickname = Le Félicia | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = StadeFHB.jpg | caption = Aerial view of the stadium in February 2009 | fullname = Stade Félix Houphouët-Boigny | former_names = Stade Géo André | location = Le Plateau, Abidjan nord, [[Abidjan]] | coordinates = {{coord|5|19|41.7|N|4|1|6.3|W|type:landmark|display=it}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1952 | renovated = 1964, 2009,2017, ''2020'' | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner =State of Cote d'Ivoire | operator = | surface = Grass | scoreboard = | cost = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = [[Mota-Engil]] (2020 renovations) | main_contractors = | capacity = 45,000https://int.soccerway.com/national/cote-divoire/ligue-1/20132014/regular-season/r22910/venues/?ICID=PL_3N_05 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = 105m x 68m | acreage = | tenants = [[ASEC Mimosas]] }} '''Stade Félix Houphouët-Boigny''', nicknamed '''Le Félicia''', is a multi-purpose stadium, which can host football, rugby union and [[Athletics (sport)|athletics]], in [[Abidjan]], [[Côte d'Ivoire]]. It is the national stadium of the [[Côte d'Ivoire national football team]]. It is named after the first president of the country, [[Félix Houphouët-Boigny]], and is located in the commune of [[Plateau, Ivory Coast|Le Plateau]]. The stadium has a capacity of 45,000.http://stadiumzone.weebly.com/ It also hosts matches of the [[ASEC Abidjan]]. It has been the site of several deadly stampedes. ==History== Built in 1964 to organize the "Games of Abidjan", the stadium was formerly known as '''Stade Andre Geo''', and it took the name of the President Felix Houphouet-Boigny after undergoing restoration. Gradually it emerged as the National Stadium, hosting the ASEC Mimosas and Ivorian Soccer Team. Along the Stadium of Peace of Bouake, Stade Felix Houphouet-Boigny hosted Africa Cup of Nations soccer. In 2009 after a complete renovation, which included lawn seating and the treatment room, the stadium hosted the [[2009 African Championship of Nations]]. The stadium was renovated for the [[2017 Jeux de la Francophonie]].{{cite web|url=http://www.abidjan2017.ci/index.php/abidjan2017/competitions-sportives/105-cnjf-en-action/379-chantiers-des-jeux-de-la-francophonie|title=CHANTIERS DES JEUX DE LA FRANCOPHONIE (French)}} The stadium played host to [[Amnesty International]]'s [[Human Rights Now!]] Benefit Concert on October 9, 1988. The show was headlined by [[Sting (musician)|Sting]] and [[Peter Gabriel]] and also featured [[Bruce Springsteen]] & The [[E Street Band]], [[Tracy Chapman]] and [[Youssou N'Dour]]. The American singer [[Chris Brown (American entertainer)|Chris Brown]] finished his [[Carpe Diem Tour]] at this stadium on December 30, 2012. The stadium is expected to host many matches of the [[2021 Africa Cup of Nations]]. It will also be renovated for this competition by [[Mota-Engil]]. ===Incidents=== On March 29, 2009, during the match between Ivory Coast and Malawi, the gateway to an open corner of the stadium gave way before the kick-off of the match. [[2009 Houphouët-Boigny stampede|A stampede ensued]] when 19 people were killed by trampling. Over 130 were injured as well. On January 1, 2013, following a New Year's Eve fireworks display, [[2013 Houphouët-Boigny stampede|another stampede]] took place, in which sixty-one lives were claimed, with upwards of 200 injuries sustained.{{cite web | last = Bakayoko | first = Inza | url = http://world.time.com/2013/01/01/ivory-coast-new-years-stampede-kills-61/ | title = Stampede After Fireworks Kills 61 in Ivory Coast | date = 2013-01-01 | publisher = [[Time (magazine)|Time]] | accessdate = 2013-01-02 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20130104104107/http://world.time.com/2013/01/01/ivory-coast-new-years-stampede-kills-61/ | archivedate = 2013-01-04 | df = }} ==Structure== The bleachers painted in national colors consist of curves, the gallery lagoon side of the podium, a gallery and a presidential box, VIP, and BVIP . The stage contains a media room, a room control used for anti-doping, a VIP room, a treatment room, offices of arbitrators, a massage room, and four dressing rooms. The stadium has a video board 220 volts for 35 kwh, 16.50 meters by 5.70 meters. The lawn is of international standard and is maintained daily green and glowing. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{wikinews|Stadium disaster claims lives at football World Cup qualifier match in Ivory Coast}} *[http://www.worldstadiums.com/stadium_pictures/africa/ivory_coast/abidjan.shtml Photo] at [http://www.worldstadiums.com/ worldstadiums.com] *[http://www.fussballtempel.net/caf/Civ/Houphouet_Boigny.html Photos] at [http://www.fussballtempel.net/ fussballtempel.net] {{s-start}} {{succession box | | title = [[African Cup of Nations]]
Final Venue| | years = [[1984 African Cup of Nations|1984]] | before = [[June 11 Stadium]]
[[Tripoli]] | after = [[Cairo International Stadium]]
[[Cairo]] }} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Felix Houphouet-Boigny}} {{2021 Africa Cup of Nations stadiums}} [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in Ivory Coast]] [[Category:Football venues in Ivory Coast]] [[Category:National stadiums]] [[Category:Sport in Abidjan]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1964]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Abidjan]] [[Category:1964 establishments in Ivory Coast]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2014}} {{Infobox stadium |stadium_name= Superior Dome |nickname= Yooper Dome |image= 2009-0618-Marquette-SuperiorDome.jpg |image_size= 300px |caption=Opposite sides of the Superior Dome |location= Northern Michigan University, [[Marquette, Michigan]], United States |broke_ground= 1991 |opened= 1991 |owner= [[Northern Michigan University]] |operator= Northern Michigan University |surface= [[FieldTurf]] |construction_cost= $23.9 million |architect= |tenants=Northern Michigan University football and other athletics ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) |seating_capacity = 8,000 }} The '''Superior Dome''', which opened as the "world’s largest wooden [[dome]]" on September 14, 1991,<ref name=hunts>{{cite web |first1= Mary |last1= Hunt |first2= Don |last2= Hunt |title= Superior Dome |url= http://hunts-upguide.com/marquette_superior_dome.html |work= Hunt's Guide to the Upper Peninsula |accessdate=November 13, 2011}}</ref> is a domed [[stadium]] on the campus of [[Northern Michigan University]] in [[Marquette, Michigan]], in the United States. It is home to the [[Northern Michigan Wildcats|Northern Michigan Wildcat]] [[American football|football]] team as well as their Marching Band, and a variety of other campus and community events.
The dome is {{convert|143|ft|m|sp=us}} tall, has a diameter of {{convert|536|ft|m}}, covers an area of {{convert|5.1|acres|m2}}, and has a volume of 16,135,907 cubic feet. It is a [[geodesic dome]] constructed with 781 [[Douglas Fir]] beams and {{convert|108.5|mi|km}} of fir decking. The dome is designed to support snow up to {{convert|60|psf|kPa}} and withstand {{convert|80|mph|km/h|adj=on}} winds. It has a permanent [[seating capacity]] of 8,000, though the building can hold as many as 16,000 people. The 2010 edition of ''[[Guinness World Records]]'' listed it as the fifth-largest dome and largest wooden dome in the world.<ref name=nmu>{{cite web|title=Superior Dome|url=http://www.nmu.edu/SuperiorDome|publisher=Northern Michigan University|accessdate=November 13, 2011}}</ref>
==Construction== The construction was finished in two phases. Phase I was finished in August 1991 and included the construction of the domed complex. Phase II, completed in May 1995, added locker rooms, department offices, meeting rooms, concession areas, a retail store and other building amenities. Phase I of the project cost $21.8 million and was funded entirely by the State of [[Michigan]]. Phase II was completed for $2.1 million, with $800,000 in private donations and $1.3 million in loans. Total cost for the Superior Dome stands at $23.9 million.
==Use== [[File:Nmu.JPG|thumb|left|Inside of Superior Dome with turf laid out]] The Wildcat football team was the first to christen the Dome, hosting the first-ever event in the facility on September 14, 1991. Northern defeated [[University of Indianapolis|Indianapolis]], 31–20, in front of a crowd of 7,942. Later that season, a Superior Dome attendance record was set at 8,432, when Northern defeated [[Ferris State University|Ferris State]], 27–17, on October 5. On September 18, 2008, a new attendance record was set as 8,672 watched Northern Michigan University lose to the [[Michigan Tech Huskies]] in a televised game.<ref>http://www.nmuwildcats.com/sports/fball/2008-09/releases/20130220tntv8v</ref>
The dome features a retractable artificial turf carpet, the largest of its kind in the world. When extended, the turf can accommodate [[American football|football]], [[football (soccer)|soccer]], and [[field hockey]]. Underneath the carpet is a synthetic playing surface that features three basketball/volleyball courts, two tennis courts and a {{convert|200|m|ft|adj=on|sp=us}} track. The carpet is winched in and out of place on a cushion of air. Retracting the turf carpet takes 30 minutes, with full setup taking approximately two hours.<ref name=nmu/>
The Superior Dome is also host to a number of campus and community events, including [[Michigan High School Athletic Association]] football regular season and playoff games, trade shows (approximately {{convert|100000|sqft|m2}} of space), conventions, conferences, banquets, high school track meets, the Upper Peninsula "[[Band Day]]" competition/exhibition, [[Special Olympics]], and NMU’s commencement exercises, to name a few.
President [[George W. Bush]] held a campaign rally in the stadium during the 2004 Presidential campaign.<ref>{{cite book|last=Bush|first=George W.|title=Public Papers of the Presidents of the United States, George W. Bush, 2004, Book 2, July 1 to September 30, 2004|year=2004|publisher=Government Printing Office|pages=1294–1300|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=l8x8VWoXjWUC}}</ref>
[[File:Superior dome.JPG|thumb|center|400px|alt=Superior Dome view from Lake Superior|Superior Dome view from [[Lake Superior]]]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071206002842/http://www.dynamiteinc.com/images/panorama/superior-dome.html 360° interactive view of the Superior Dome]

revision.text:
{{Coord|39|21|31.01|N|74|27|031.11|W|display=title}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Surf Stadium | image = | location = 545 North Albany Avenue
[[Atlantic City, New Jersey|Atlantic City, NJ]] 08401 | broke_ground = 1996| opened = 1998 | operator = Atlantic City Surf (1998-2008) [[Atlantic Cape Community College]] Buccaneers (2014-Present)| construction_cost = $15 million | architect = | surface = Natural grass | former_names = The Sandcastle (1998-2006) Bernie Robbins Stadium (2006-2008) | tenants = [[Atlantic City Surf]] ([[Atlantic League of Professional Baseball|Atlantic League]]/[[Canadian-American Association of Professional Baseball|Can-Am League]]) (1998-2008) [[Atlantic Cape Community College]] Buccaneers (2014-Present) | seating_capacity = 5,500 | dimensions = Left Field: {{convert|309|ft|m}} Center Field: {{convert|400|ft|m}} Right Field: {{convert|309|ft|m}} }} '''Surf Stadium''' is a 5,500-seat baseball stadium in [[Atlantic City, New Jersey]] that opened in 1998 and has been mostly closed since 2009, although some renovation was performed in 2011 and 2012. The stadium was officially renamed as '''Surf Stadium''' in April 2012, and hosted a few events in 2012. The stadium was called '''The Sandcastle''' until 2006, and has continued to be referred to by that name in some sources. It was built as the home of the [[Atlantic City Surf]] baseball team, which discontinued operations prior to the 2009 season. College and youth[http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/communities/atlantic-city_pleasantville_brigantine/baseball-is-back-at-atlantic-city-s-surf-stadium-with/article_826bd650-dce9-11e1-bd5a-0019bb2963f4.html Baseball is back at Atlantic City's Surf Stadium with start of Babe Ruth tournament], ''[[Press of Atlantic City]]'', Aug. 3, 2012 teams have also used the stadium, and a music concert was held there in 2011. The stadium is located on Albany Avenue, near the eastern terminus of [[U.S. Route 40 in New Jersey|U.S. Routes 40]] and [[U.S. Route 322 in New Jersey|322]] and several blocks inland from the [[Boardwalk#Atlantic City, New Jersey|Boardwalk]] and [[casino]] strip. The casinos are visible from the seating areas. Seating is in two primary sections, split by a "cross aisle". Luxury boxes are located above the main seating bowl. It is now the home stadium of the Atlantic Cape Community College Buccaneers baseball team. ==History== The stadium, originally known as The Sandcastle, opened in 1998 on a parcel located on the sprawling [[Bader Field]], a closed municipal airport. When the park first opened, the seating sections were named for the various properties on the U.S. version of the [[Monopoly (game)|Monopoly]] board, which took its names from the streets of Atlantic City and surrounding towns. However, saying "I'm sitting in Pacific Avenue" was not sufficiently descriptive, and so the seating sections were assigned numbers, as at most other stadiums. In 2006, the Bernie Robbins jewelry chain purchased the naming rights and the stadium was renamed as "Bernie Robbins Stadium".{{cite web | title=Jeweler Buys Local Stadium Naming Rights | date=May 23, 2006 | work=6abc.com | publisher=[[WPVI-TV]] | url=http://abclocal.go.com/wpvi/story?section=news/sports&id=4196678 | accessdate=February 11, 2011}} Sand Stadium (then known as Bernie Robbins Stadium) played host to the [[Atlantic League of Professional Baseball|Atlantic League]] All-Star Game in 1998 and 2005 as well as to various amateur baseball events and concerts. In October 2006, it was the venue for [[2008 Rugby League World Cup qualifying|Atlantic regional qualifying]] for the [[2008 Rugby League World Cup]]. In May 2008, [[WCAU-TV]] sports director and former [[NFL]] player [[Vai Sikahema]] accepted an open challenge from former [[MLB]] player [[Jose Canseco]] to fight him in a celebrity boxing match for $5,000. Canseco claims to have earned black belts in [[Kung Fu]], [[Taekwondo]], and [[Muay Thai]], while Sikahema, who grew up wanting to be a professional boxer, had once fought in a National Golden Gloves Championship that was eventually won by [[Sugar Ray Leonard]]. The fight, dubbed the "War At The Shore", took place on July 12, 2008, and was hosted by Philadelphia-native adult film personality Steven Sheaffer. Sikahema won by knockout in the first round.[http://www.nbc10.com/news/16866470/detail.html "Vai Wins War At The Shore"], NBC10.com, July 13, 2008. Accessed July 13, 2008. After the stadium closed, its condition seriously deteriorated due to lack of maintenance and vandalism.{{cite web | title=Battered up! Atlantic City's Bernie Robbins Stadium falls into disrepair | url=http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/news/press/atlantic_city/article_cbe3176c-9237-11de-a86a-001cc4c03286.html |work=[[Press of Atlantic City]] | accessdate=September 4, 2009 |date = August 27, 2009}}{{cite web | title=Wasted Potential | url=http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/opinion/editorials/article_2ac5b733-823a-5429-b020-8afeb94e955d.html |work=[[Press of Atlantic City]] | accessdate= September 4, 2009 }}{{cite web | title=Bernie Robbins Stadium's disrepair is a personal thing for owner of Bernie Robbins name | url=http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/news/breaking/article_708a20b2-96ed-11de-bba3-001cc4c002e0.html |work=[[Press of Atlantic City]] | accessdate=September 4, 2009 }}[http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/news/breaking/article_87899fe4-fa61-11df-8cda-001cc4c03286.html Crowds, players long gone from abandoned Atlantic City baseball stadium], ''[[Press of Atlantic City]]'', Nov. 28, 2010. However, the abandoned stadium received considerable restoration in 2011 to prepare it to be used as a VIP area for a three-day musical festival headlined by the [[Dave Matthews Band]] that was held at the former Bader Field airport. Most of the improvements focused on repairing the facility's fire-suppression system and plumbing, as well as rejuvenating the field itself. The stadium was used for VIP seating for special ticket holders for the festival, and for a "Summer Fest" concert featuring rapper [[Rick Ross]].{{cite web |title=Atlantic City government likely to lose money on Dave Matthews Band festival |url=http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/news/press/atlantic_city/atlantic-city-government-likely-to-lose-money-on-dave-matthews/article_eabaf09e-7eab-11e0-a7f4-001cc4c002e0.html |author=Michael Clark |work=[[Press of Atlantic City]] |date=2011-05-15 |accessdate=2011-05-15}} In April 2012, the stadium was officially renamed as "Surf Stadium",[http://www.pressofatlanticcity.com/communities/atlantic-city_pleasantville_brigantine/atlantic-city-s-sandcastle-stadium-officially-renamed-surf-stadium/article_0531cc86-84af-11e1-97c2-001a4bcf887a.html Atlantic City's Sandcastle Stadium Officially Renamed Surf Stadium], ''[[Press of Atlantic City]]'', April 12, 2012 and after additional renovation work, a youth baseball league tournament was held there in August 2012.[http://www.shorenewstoday.com/snt/news/index.php/region-sports/atlantic-county-sports/28071-regional-tournament-brings-baseball-back-to-surf-stadium.html Regional tournament brings baseball back to Surf Stadium] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140422232250/http://www.shorenewstoday.com/snt/news/index.php/region-sports/atlantic-county-sports/28071-regional-tournament-brings-baseball-back-to-surf-stadium.html |date=2014-04-22 }}, ''Shore News Today'', Aug. 1, 2012. ==See also== *[[Bader Field|Bader Field Airport]] *[[Bader Field (ballpark)]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{AC Surf}} [[Category:Buildings and structures in Atlantic City, New Jersey]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Atlantic County, New Jersey]] [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Atlantic City, New Jersey]] [[Category:1998 establishments in New Jersey]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1998]] [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]]

Pictures | released = August 15, 1936 | runtime = 64 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | website = }} '''''Two-Fisted Gentleman''''' is a 1936 American [[drama film]] directed by [[Gordon Wiles]] and starring [[James Dunn (actor)|James Dunn]], [[June Clayworth]] and [[George McKay (actor)|George McKay]].Romano p.70 ==Premise== Mickey rises from obscurity to become a top prizefighter, but in the process alienates girlfriend Ginger and takes up with a scheming blonde, June. ==Cast== * [[James Dunn (actor)|James Dunn]] as Mickey * [[June Clayworth]] as Ginger * [[George McKay (actor)|George McKay]] as Schmidty * [[Thurston Hall]] as Pop * [[Gene Morgan]] as Porky * [[Paul Guilfoyle (actor, born 1902)|Paul Guilfoyle]] as Gallagher * [[Harry Tyler (actor)|Harry Tyler]] as Fieldsie * [[Muriel Evans]] as June Prentice * [[Charles Lane (actor)|Charles Lane]] as Joe Gordon * [[John Hamilton (actor)|John Hamilton]] as Frank Boyd * [[Brenda Fowler]] as Mrs. Prentice * [[Sarah Edwards (actress)|Sarah Edwards]] as Mrs. O'Shea * [[Arthur Loft]] as Fletcher * [[Fred Kohler Jr.]] as Conklin * [[George Cleveland]] as Mr. Bainbridge * [[May Wallace]] as Mrs. Bainbridge * [[Edward LeSaint]] as Judge * [[Max Wagner]] as First Beggar * [[Eddie Sturgis]] as Second Beggar * [[Ralph Byrd]] as Charley * [[George Magrill]] as Tiger * [[Beatrice Blinn]] as Secretary * [[Wilson Benge]] as Butler * [[John Tyrrell (actor)|John Tyrrell]] as Man in Lunch Wagon * [[Arthur Rankin (actor)|Arthur Rankin]] as Walker]] as Policeman * [[Freeman Wood]] * [[Bruce Sidney]] * [[Reginald Simpson]] * [[Bess Flowers]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Bibliography== * Frederick V. Romano. ''The Boxing Filmography: American Features, 1920-2003''. {{Expand French|Auditorium de Verdun|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name=Verdun Auditorium | nickname=Auditorium de Verdun | image=The Verdun Auditorium.jpg | location=4110, boulevard LaSalle, [[Verdun, Quebec|Verdun]], [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]] H4G 2A5 | broke_ground= | opened=November 28, 1939 | owner=City of Montreal | construction_cost= | architect= | former_names= | tenants=[[Montreal Junior Hockey Club]] ([[Quebec Major Junior Hockey League|QMJHL]]) (2008-2011)

[[Montreal Dragons]] (NBL) (1993)
[[Verdun Collège Français]] (QMJHL) (1991–1994)
[[Verdun Juniors]] (QMJHL) (1982–1984)

[[Verdun Maple Leafs (ice hockey)|Verdun Maple Leafs]] (QMJHL) (1920s-1972) | seating_capacity=[[ice hockey|Hockey]]: 3,795 seated (4,114 total) }} '''Verdun Auditorium''' is an [[arena]] located in the [[Montreal]] borough of [[Verdun, Quebec|Verdun]], [[Quebec]], Canada. The building was constructed in 1938 and holds 4,114. The largest arena in the west end of Montreal, the complex is also home to Arena Denis Savard, a small minor-hockey rink, attached to its side. The Auditorium has hosted various [[Quebec Major Junior Hockey League]] teams, including the [[Verdun Juniors]], [[Verdun Éperviers]] and [[Verdun Collège Français]]. In 1993 it also hosted the [[Montreal Dragons]] for its lone season in the short lived [[National Basketball League (1993-94 Canadian league)|National Basketball League]]. It is slated to become the home arena of [[Les Canadiennes de Montreal]] in 2019.http://montrealgazette.com/sports/hockey/les-canadiennes-to-move-into-the-verdun-auditorium-in-2019 On January 25, 2008, the QMJHL approved the sale of the [[St. John's Fog Devils]] to [[Montreal]] businessman [[Farrel Miller]],[http://www.lhjmq.qc.ca/lang_en/index.php?page=232&id_nouvelle=1667 QMJHL set to return to Montreal next season]{{dead link|date=July 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} who relocated the team to Montreal, where it was known as the [[Montreal Junior Hockey Club]]. In the summer of 2011, the team moved to [[Boisbriand, Quebec|Boisbriand]] to become the [[Blainville-Boisbriand Armada]]. The auditorium also received the American punk band Nirvana on November 2, 1993. This was the band's last show in Montreal before frontman Kurt Cobain died five months later.[http://www.livenirvana.com/dvd/1993/dvd_11-02-93.php Nirvana at Auditorium de Verdun 11/02/93] ==References== ==External links== * [http://www.qmjhlarenaguide.com/verdun.htm QMJHL Arena & Travel Guide] {{coord|45.462448|N|73.561878|W|region:CA-QC_type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Indoor arenas in Quebec]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in Canada]] [[Category:Quebec Major Junior Hockey League arenas]] [[Category:Sports venues in Montreal]] [[Category:Verdun, Quebec]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1939]] [[Category:1939 establishments in Quebec]] {{canada-icehockey-venue-stub}}

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Veterans Memorial Stadium | nickname = | image = LBMemorialStadium1.jpg | image_size = 275px | image_caption = | location = Lew Davis St.,
[[Long Beach, California|Long Beach, CA]] | coordinates = {{Coord|33|49|41.66|N|118|8|10.13|W|type:landmark|display=title,inline}} | broke_ground = | opened = 1948 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Long Beach City College]] | operator = [[Long Beach City College]] | surface = SprinTurf | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = | seating_capacity = 11,600 | record_attendance = | tenants = [[Long Beach City College]]
[[California Interscholastic Federation]]
[[Los Angeles Bulldogs|Long Beach Bulldogs]] (1948)
[[Long Beach State 49ers football]] (1955–1976,1983–1992)
[[Long Beach Admirals]] (1967) }} [[File:Veterans Memorial Stadium (Long Beach).jpg|thumb|right|277px|Veterans Memorial Stadium - Opened in 1948]] '''Veterans Memorial Stadium''' (also known as '''Veterans Stadium''', '''Vets Stadium''' or simply '''The Vet''') is an 11,600-seat stadium located south of the Liberal Arts Campus of [[Long Beach City College]] in [[Long Beach, California]]. It is the home stadium to a number of local area high school football teams, as well as [[Long Beach City College]]'s football team.{{cite web|title=Veterans Memorial Stadium|publisher=lbcc.edu|url=https://www.lbcc.edu/contact/veterans-memorial-stadium |accessdate=2017-10-18}} It was also home to [[Long Beach State 49ers football|Long Beach State]]'s football team until the program disbanded in 1991.{{cite news| last =Woolard| first =John| title =Football gets sacked at CSULB| work =The Long Beach Press-Telegram| date =December 11, 1991}} The stadium is also popular as a movie set for a number of [[Hollywood]] [[motion picture]]s.{{cite web|title=Most Popular Titles With Location Matching "Veterans Memorial Stadium|publisher=imdb.com|url=https://www.imdb.com/search/title?locations=Veterans%20Memorial%20Stadium%20-%20508%20E.%20Lew%20Davis%20Street,%20Long%20Beach,%20California,%20USA|accessdate=2017-10-18}} It also hosted the 1985 and 1988 Motorcycle [[Speedway World Team Cup]] Finals. ==History== Veterans Stadium opened in 1948, and was owned by the City of Long Beach for a number of decades. The City of Long Beach used the stadium as a temporary location for Fire Station 19 (now located on Clark Avenue, a few blocks away). The fire station was housed at the south end of the stadium under the bleacher area; the large door that was installed for the fire engine to exit can still be seen. The actual "station", or living quarters area, is now used as an office for stadium personnel. Soon after the stadium opened, the [[Los Angeles Bulldogs]] of the [[Pacific Coast Professional Football League]] became the Long Beach Bulldogs for the 1948 season.[http://profootballresearchers.com/archives/Website_Files/Coffin_Corner/05-04-135.pdf The End of the PCPFL] – Bob Gill, Pro Football Research Association (1983) But the minor-league PCPFL was on its last legs by this time, and so were the Bulldogs—a legendary West Coast team that had fallen on hard times since the NFL [[Los Angeles Rams]] and the [[All-America Football Conference|AAFC]]'s [[Los Angeles Dons]] moved to town. After drawing just 850 fans for a Bulldogs game in Long Beach, the team promptly cancelled the rest of their schedule, and the PCPFL folded soon after. Two decades later, in 1967, the Vet hosted professional football again. The [[Long Beach Admirals]] were admitted to the [[Continental Football League]] as part of the league's expansion to the west coast. But the Admirals wouldn't last long: they drew only 2,475 fans for an exhibition game, then just 950 customers for their regular season opener, a 37-13 loss to the [[Seattle Rangers]]. After the disastrous gates, the Admirals applied for an immediate transfer to [[Portland, Oregon]]; this was denied, and the Admirals sank beneath the waves. In 1987, Long Beach City College acquired Veterans Stadium from the City of Long Beach, and in the 1990s, the college upgraded the stadium for use by local high school football teams. One of the most memorable football contests held at the stadium involved [[Long Beach Polytechnic High School]] and Lakewood High School, drawing over 11,500 spectators and regional television coverage. Veterans Stadium is currently the home stadium to the Long Beach Poly Jackrabbits and the [[Los Alamitos High School]] Griffins. ===Speedway=== During the 1980s the stadium also doubled as a [[Motorcycle speedway]] venue. The speedway track was laid out over the stadiums existing {{convert|400|m|yd}} athletics track with additional banking in the corners to allow for faster racing. As well as hosting the World Team Cup Final in [[1985 Speedway World Team Cup|1985]] and [[1988 Speedway World Team Cup|1988]] (both won by [[Denmark national speedway team|Denmark]] with the [[United States national speedway team|USA]] finishing second), the stadium played host to numerous American Finals which were then qualifying rounds for the [[Speedway World Championship]] during the decade. Some of the riders to have raced at the stadium include Individual World Champions [[Bruce Penhall]] and [[Sam Ermolenko]] (USA), [[Erik Gundersen]] and [[Hans Nielsen (speedway rider)|Hans Nielsen]] ([[Denmark]]), [[Per Jonsson]] ([[Sweden]]) and [[Gary Havelock]] ([[England]]), as well as a host of top class riders such as Americans [[Shawn Moran|Shawn]] and [[Kelly Moran (speedway rider)|Kelly Moran]], [[Bobby Schwartz]] and [[Scott Autrey]]. Veterans is also the site where [[Dennis Sigalos]] ended his career with a badly broken leg following a crash in the 1984 American Final. ===Rugby League=== Probably the most historically notable football contest at this stadium involved a completely different code—[[rugby league]]. In [[1987 Rugby League State of Origin series|1987]], after the three regular matches in the [[Australia]]n [[State of Origin series]] between the states of [[Queensland rugby league team|Queensland]] and [[New South Wales rugby league team|New South Wales]], the two teams went to Long Beach for a fourth match, drawing an announced crowd of 12,439 to see New South Wales win 30–18. The canonicity of the match [[Rugby League State of Origin#1987: American controversy|has been in dispute]] ever since. While all Australian authorities count the match for purposes of individual player statistics, not all of them include it in official team records. Sources in [[New South Wales]], including the [[Australian Rugby League]] and its successor, the [[Australian Rugby League Commission]], officially count the match result; those within the [[Queensland Rugby League]] do not. In 2004, Veterans Stadium received another upgrade. A new [[SprinTurf]] playing surface replaced the old playing surface in time for the 2004 football season. ===Soccer=== Veterans Memorial Stadium hosted a match in the [[1958 FIFA World Cup qualification]]. ==About Veterans Stadium== ===The basics=== Veterans Stadium seats 11,600, and are on one side of the stadium, a grandstand facing east. 7,000 of the seats are aluminum bench bleachers, with the other 4,600 seats having fixed chairbacks. The field is surrounded by a nine-lane, 400-meter track. ===Location=== The stadium is located on Lew Davis Street between Clark Avenue and Faculty Avenue. It is three miles west of Interstate 605 (use the Carson Street exit) and two miles north of Interstate 405 (use the Lakewood Boulevard exit or the Bellflower Boulevard exit). ===Technical information=== The field is open at both ends and there is a practice field on the north side and a large parking lot on the south side. There are large locker rooms for both home and visiting teams in the stadium and a smaller room for game officials. There are lights for night play using [[metal-halide lamp]]s on eight towers. Veterans Stadium also features a two-level press box (capacity 100) atop the west grandstand. Spectator amenities include 4,000 surface parking spaces, two ticket booths with two windows each, three permanent concessions, and a combined message board and scoreboard. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.lasports.org/lafacilities/display.php?s=Stadium&id=56 Veterans Stadium] from Los Angeles Sports Council {{Long Beach State 49ers football navbox}} {{California State University, Long Beach}} [[Category:American football venues in California]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Long Beach, California]] [[Category:Rugby League State of Origin]] [[Category:Rugby league stadiums in the United States]] [[Category:Soccer venues in California]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in California]] [[Category:Motorsport venues in California]] [[Category:College football venues]] [[Category:Long Beach State 49ers football]] [[Category:Monuments and memorials in California]] [[Category:1948 establishments in California]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1948]] [[Category:Sports venues in Long Beach, California]] [[Category:High school football venues in California]]

{{distinguish|Vidarbha Cricket Association Ground}} {{Use Indian English|date=April 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2011}} {{Infobox cricket ground | ground_name = Vidarbha Cricket Association Stadium | nickname = New VCA Stadium | image = VCA Nagpur,India.jpg | caption = VCA Stadium at Jamtha, Nagpur | country = India | location = [[Nagpur]], [[Maharashtra]] |architect = [[Shashi Prabhu]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Rajaram |first=Sowmya |url=http://www.mid-day.com/news/2011/mar/270311-wankhede-stadium-narrow-seats-mumbai.htm |title=Going for WC finals? You've bought backache and discomfort for Rs 12,500 |publisher=Mid-day.com |date=2011-03-27 |accessdate=2012-12-13}}</ref> | establishment = 2008 | seating_capacity = 45,000 | owner = [[Vidarbha Cricket Association]] | operator = [[Vidarbha Cricket Association]] | tenants = [[Vidarbha cricket team]] | end1 = Secretary End | end2 = Pavilion End | firsttestdate = 6–10 November | firsttestyear = 2008 | firsttesthome = India | firsttestaway = Australia | lasttestdate = 24–28 November | lasttestyear = 2017 | lasttesthome = India | lasttestaway = Sri Lanka | firstodidate = 28 October | firstodiyear = 2009 | firstodihome = India | firstodiaway = Australia | lastodidate = 1 October | lastodiyear = 2017 | lastodihome = India | lastodiaway = Australia | firstt20idate = 9 December | firstt20iyear = 2009 | firstt20ihome = India | firstt20iaway = Sri Lanka | lastt20idate = 29 January | lastt20iyear = 2017 | lastt20ihome = India | lastt20iaway = England | date = 24 November | year = 2017 | source = http://www.cricinfo.com/india/content/ground/375326.html Cricinfo }}
The '''Vidarbha Cricket Association Stadium''' ({{lang-mr|विदर्भ क्रिकेट असोसिएशन स्टेडियम}}) also known as '''New VCA''' stadium is a [[cricket]] ground in [[Nagpur]], [[Maharashtra]], [[India]]. It is the largest cricket stadium in [[India]] in terms of field area.
The ground, located at Jamtha on the southern outskirts of Nagpur, was inaugurated in 2008, replacing the old [[Vidarbha Cricket Association Ground]] as the city's main stadium. The qualities of the stadium have been praised by the [[International Cricket Council]].<ref>[http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2010-07-02/top-stories/28322831_1_host-third-vca-stadium-wankhede-stadium Nagpur likely to host third India-New Zealand Test – Times Of India]. Articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com (2010-07-02). Retrieved on 2013-12-23.</ref>
VCA Stadium is the home ground for the [[Vidarbha cricket team|Vidarbha]] and [[Central Zone cricket team|Central Zone]] teams for the domestic [[Ranji Trophy]] and [[Duleep Trophy]] tournaments, respectively. As of 19 August 2017 it has hosted five [[Test cricket|Tests]], seven ODIs and 11 T20Is.
==Overview== [[File:VCA.svg|thumb|Layout of the VCA Stadium]]
[[Sachin Tendulkar]] said "the facilities exceeded all expectations" and [[Ricky Ponting]] commented on the comfort in the changing rooms.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/indvaus2008/content/story/377218.html|title=Spectator-friendly minus the spectators|work=Cricinfo}}</ref> [[Rajasthan Royals]] skipper [[Shane Warne]] was extremely pleased with the "largeness of the ground" after his team’s two-run win over [[Deccan Chargers]]. "[[Michael Lumb (cricketer)|Michael Lumb]]'s slog to deep mid-wicket found a fielder. Now, if this was [[M. A. Chidambaram Stadium]] or [[M. Chinnaswamy Stadium]], then that ball would have landed in a taxi going to the team hotel. We need big grounds like these," Warne said.<ref>[http://www.dnaindia.com/sport/report-bowlers-in-with-a-chance-at-the-vca-stadium-in-nagpur-1370289 Bowlers in with a chance at the VCA stadium in Nagpur – Sport – DNA]. Dnaindia.com. Retrieved on 2013-12-23.</ref> It has 80-yard straight boundaries and 85-yard square boundaries, which makes it one of the largest grounds (in terms of playing area) in the world.<ref name="autogenerated2">[http://www.bcci.tv/bcci/bccitv/community/venues/venue/4d1dd0ab8f09d ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131102005833/http://www.bcci.tv/bcci/bccitv/community/venues/venue/4d1dd0ab8f09d |date=2 November 2013 }}</ref>
[[Lalit Modi]] said the VCA was "by far the best stadium in India". The stadium has been praised not only by the players but also by commentators and journalists because of the facilities.<ref name="autogenerated2"/> [[Alan Wilkins (cricketer)|Alan Wilkins]] said, "It is a fabulous stadium, a Colosseum here in [[Nagpur]]. It has the most impressive [[Press box]] for the travelling media. It really is a wonderful venue."
The first international match at this venue was the Fourth Test between [[India cricket team|India]] and [[Australia cricket team|Australia]] in November 2008, which India won by 172 runs. The Australian spinner [[Jason Krejza]] finished with 12 wickets, while [[Harbhajan Singh]] claimed seven for India.
Four matches were played at the stadium during the [[2011 Cricket World Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://icc-cricket.yahoo.net/events_and_awards/CWC/fixtures.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=15 December 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100110075851/http://icc-cricket.yahoo.net/events_and_awards/CWC/fixtures.php |archivedate=10 January 2010 }}</ref> The highest Test scores are by India: 566/8, 558/6 and 441. The leading run scorers in Tests are Virendar Sehwag (357), Sachin Tendulkar (289) and Hashim Amla(253). The leading wicket takers in a Test are Harbhajan Singh (13 wickets), Jason Krejza (12) and Ishant Sharma (11). The highest ODI scores are by India 354/6, India 351/4, Australia 350/6, New Zealand 302/7 and India 301/7. The leading scorers in ODIs are [[Mahendra Singh Dhoni]] (243), Sachin Tendulkar(158) and Gautam Gambhir (147). The leading wicket takers in ODIs are Mitchell Johnson (7 wickets), Dale Steyn (5) and Harbhajan Singh (5).
{{wide image|Panoramic view of VCA stadium,nagpur.jpg|1100px|align-cap=center|Panoramic view of VCA stadium,nagpur|Height=280}}
==Various Format Record== {{main|List of international cricket centuries at the Vidarbha Cricket Association Stadium}}
===Test Records=== * '''Highest team total''': 610/6d, by [[India national cricket team|India]] against [[Sri Lanka national cricket team|Sri Lanka]] in 2017/18. * '''Lowest team total''': 79, by [[South African national cricket team|South Africa]] against [[Indian national cricket team|India]] in 2015/16. * '''Highest individual score''': 253[[not out|*]], by [[Hashim Amla]] (South Africa) against [[Indian national cricket team|India]] in 2010/11. * '''Best bowling in an innings''': 8/215, by [[Jason Krejza]] (Australia) against [[India national cricket team|India]] in 2008/09. *'''Most runs scored by a player''': [[Virendar Sehwag]] 357. *'''Most wickets taken''': [[R Ashwin]] 19.
===ODI Records=== * '''Highest team total''': 354/7, by [[India cricket team|India]] against [[Australian national cricket team|Australia]] in 2009/10<ref>[http://www.espncricinfo.com/indvaus2009/content/story/431723.html Big-hitting Dhoni helps level series | India v Australia, 2nd ODI, Nagpur Report | Cricket News]. ESPN Cricinfo. Retrieved on 2013-12-23.</ref> * '''Lowest team total''': 123, by [[Canadian national cricket team|Canada]] against [[Zimbabwean national cricket team|Zimbabwe]] on 28 February 2011. * '''Highest individual score''': 156, by [[George Bailey (cricketer, born 1982)|George Bailey]] against [[Indian national cricket team|India]] in 2013/14. *"Most runs scored by a player": [[MS Dhoni]]- 268 runs, [[Shane Watson]]- 183 runs and [[Virat Kohli]]- 170 runs. * '''Best bowling in an innings''': 4/33, by [[Mitchell Johnson (cricketer)|Mitchell Johnson]] against [[New Zealand national cricket team|New Zealand]] in February 2011. *'''Most wickets taken''': [[Mitchell Johnson (cricketer)|Mitchell Johnson]]- 9 wickets, [[Dale Steyn]], [[Ravindra Jadeja]] and [[Harbhajan Singh]]- 5 wickets.
===T20I Records=== * '''Highest team total''': 219/5, by [[Sri Lanka national cricket team|Sri Lanka]] against [[India national cricket team|India]] in 2009/10. * '''Lowest team total''': 79/10, by [[Indian national cricket team|India]] against [[New Zealand national cricket team|New Zealand]] in 2016/17. * '''Highest individual score''': 78, by [[Kumar Sangakkara]] against [[Indian national cricket team|India]] in 2009/10. * '''Best bowling in an innings''': 4/11 by [[Mitchell Santner]] against [[Indian national cricket team|India]] in 2016/17.
==Gallery== <gallery class=center mode=packed heights=165 caption="Photo Gallery of the VCA Stadium"> File:Scorecard control room.jpg|The on ground scorecard and big screen control room File:VCA stadium.jpg|VCA at night File:Corporate box.jpg|The corporate box in north wing </gallery>

{{Refimprove|date=September 2008}} '''Woodcar Independent Racing League''' (WIRL) is an independent racing league for pinewood car builders.
Pinewood car racing was popularized by the well known [[Boy Scouts of America|Boy Scout]] sanctioned [[Pinewood Derby]]. Unlike the Scout races, WIRL races are open to people of all ages and participants are not required to be a member of any particular organization. To compete in WIRL racing events, cars are sent to a central location where they are raced together on the same track. Cars can race for one year under one of four sets of rules: Rookie,<ref name="wirlracing">{{cite web|url=http://wirlracing.com/rookie.shtml|title=WIRL Racing Official Site...Events|author=WIRL|publisher=wirlracing.com|accessdate=2016-05-15}}</ref> Pure Stock,<ref name="wirlracing2">{{cite web|url=http://wirlracing.com/pure-stock.shtml|title=WIRL Racing Official Site...Pure Stock|author=WIRL|publisher=wirlracing.com|accessdate=2016-05-15}}</ref> Pro Stock<ref name="wirlracing3">{{cite web|url=http://wirlracing.com/pro-stock.shtml|title=WIRL Racing Official Site...Events|author=WIRL|publisher=wirlracing.com|accessdate=2016-05-15}}</ref> and Modified.<ref name="wirlracing4">{{cite web|url=http://wirlracing.com/Modified.shtml|title=WIRL Racing Official Site...Modified|author=WIRL|publisher=wirlracing.com|accessdate=2016-05-15}}</ref>

[[FC Kremin Kremenchuk|Kremin]] | seating_capacity = 2,500 ([[football (soccer)|football]]) | dimensions = }} '''Yunist Stadium''' ({{lang-uk|Стадіон Юність}}) is a [[football (soccer)|football]] [[stadium]] in [[Horishni Plavni]].{{uk icon}} [http://www.fcvorskla.com.ua/links/ukraine/hirnyk-sport.htm FC Hirnyk-Sport Komsomolsk] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090621125553/http://www.fcvorskla.com.ua/links/ukraine/hirnyk-sport.htm |date=June 21, 2009 }} For [[Ukrainian Second League 2008-09]] season the stadium is a home arena for [[FC Hirnyk-Sport Komsomolsk]] and [[FC Kremin Kremenchuk]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110724025920/http://www.gornyak.com.ua/?lev=stadion Younist Stadium] {{FC Kremin Kremenchuk}} {{Ukraine-sports-venue-stub}} {{coord|49|00|15|N|33|38|53|E|region:UA_source:kolossus-ukwiki|display=title}} [[Category:Football venues in Poltava Oblast]] [[Category:FC Kremin Kremenchuk]] [[Category:FC Hirnyk-Sport Komsomolsk]] [[Category:Sports venues in Poltava Oblast]]
